extracted_ttps.description: The attackers sent a malicious document, likely via a phishing email, which was opened by the user of the infected machine.
The attackers used mshta.exe to execute an HTA file hosted on a remote server, potentially bypassing application control solutions.
The attackers relied on the user to open a malicious document, which initiated the attack chain.
The attackers used cmd.exe to execute various commands, including ipconfig and ping.
The attackers used Remote Manipulator System (RMS) and UltraVNC to conduct lateral movement.
The attacker used command and scripting interpreter to execute a command
Detected Phishing activity via NLP pattern matching
The attacker used user execution to run a malicious file

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
extracted_ttps.description: The attacker exfiltrated data over a command and control channel
The attackers used wscript.exe to execute a malicious VBS file (depended.lnk).
The attackers used cmd.exe to execute various commands, including ping and ipconfig.
The attackers accessed and opened various documents on the compromised machine.
The attackers created scheduled tasks to ensure persistence between system reboots.
The attacker used system information discovery to gather system information
The attacker collected data from the local system
The attacker used remote services to move laterally
The attacker used Visual Basic scripting to execute a command
Detected Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Command and Scripting Interpreter activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Exfiltration Over C2 Channel activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Scheduled Task/Job activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Remote Desktop Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Suspicious Office Child Process Execution
rules.description: Detects Office applications spawning command-line shells, which may indicate execution from a malicious document received via spearphishing.

detection.condition: selection_office and selection_suspicious_child and not (ParentImage|endswith='\smsagenthost.exe' or ParentImage|endswith='\IntuneManagementAgentService.exe' or ParentImage|endswith='\TrustedInstaller.exe' or ParentImage|endswith='\usoclient.exe') and (CommandLine|length >= 100 or CommandLine|contains='-enc' or CommandLine|contains='Invoke-' or CommandLine|contains='IEX')

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts launched from Office documents in enterprise environments
User-triggered macros that invoke command-line tools for valid purposes
Software update mechanisms that use Office automation (rare)

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious mshta.exe Execution of Remote HTA File
rules.description: Detects mshta.exe executing an HTA file from a remote location, often used to bypass application control. Includes checks for long command lines and suspicious parent processes while excluding known management tools.

detection.condition: selection and t1_exec and (suspicious_parent or long_command) and not exclusion_parent

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using mshta.exe with long command lines
Internal applications or help systems launching local HTA files via mshta.exe
Software deployment tools (e.g., SCCM, Intune) executing mshta in managed environments

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious Process Spawned from Document Application
rules.description: Detects when a document application (e.g., Word, Excel) spawns a potentially malicious child process such as PowerShell, CMD, or script hosts with suspicious command line characteristics.

detection.condition: selection_parent and selection_child and selection_command_length and not exclusion_benign

falsepositives: Legitimate macro-enabled documents spawning command-line tools for administrative tasks
Enterprise management tools (e.g., SCCM, Intune) updating configurations via document integrations (excluded)
PowerShell scripts launched by Office apps for legitimate automation (rare with long encoded commands)

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious Command and Scripting Interpreter Activity via cmd.exe
rules.description: Detects suspicious execution of cmd.exe, particularly when spawned by potentially malicious parent processes or executing network reconnaissance commands like ipconfig and ping. Includes detection of long encoded command lines and excludes known benign management tools.

detection.condition: selection_cmd and (selection_commands or selection_suspicious_parent or selection_long_command) and not filter_benign

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that use cmd.exe with ipconfig or ping for diagnostics
Software deployment tools (e.g., SCCM, Intune) launching cmd.exe for configuration tasks
Long command lines in automated build or deployment scripts

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Remote Services Lateral Movement via RMS or UltraVNC
rules.description: Detect execution of Remote Manipulator System (RMS) or UltraVNC binaries and their outbound network connections, indicating possible lateral movement using remote services.

detection.condition: selection_rms or selection_uvnc or selection_rms_net or selection_uvnc_net

falsepositives: Legitimate remote administration or support sessions using UltraVNC or RMS by IT staff
Authorized use of RMS/UltraVNC in managed environments

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Phishing via Office Document Execution of Suspicious Shells
rules.description: Detects potential phishing attempts where Office applications spawn command-line interpreters or scripting hosts, often used to execute malicious payloads. Includes detection of unusually long encoded command lines and excludes known legitimate update or management tools.
falsepositives: Legitimate Office macros or add‑ins that launch PowerShell or cmd for automation
IT administration scripts that use Office as a launcher for legitimate tasks
Software deployment tools that invoke mshta.exe or rundll32.exe in a controlled manner

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel via Suspicious Process
rules.description: Detects potential exfiltration over C2 channel by identifying process creation events involving known malicious domains, suspicious parent processes, and long encoded command lines.

detection.condition: selection_domain and selection_executable and selection_parent and selection_long_command and not exclusion_benign

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using long command lines and calling external domains
Internal testing tools that simulate C2-like behavior
Misconfigured management software using non-standard update channels
rules.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious Windows Command Shell Usage with Network Commands
rules.description: Detects execution of cmd.exe with network diagnostic commands (ping, ipconfig) which may indicate adversary command and control or reconnaissance activity. Excludes known benign management tools and includes checks for suspicious parent processes and long command lines.

detection.condition: selection_cmd and selection_commands and not exclusion_benign_parents and not exclusion_benign_commands and (condition_suspicious_parent or condition_long_command)

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative use of cmd.exe with ping or ipconfig by system administrators
Automated IT management tools (e.g., SCCM, Intune) executing network commands during inventory or health checks
User-initiated network troubleshooting via command line from explorer.exe

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious Document Access via Unusual Launchers
rules.description: Detects processes opening office documents when launched by suspicious parent processes or with unusually long command lines, indicating possible data collection from the local system.

detection.condition: selection_doc and (suspicious_parent or long_cmd) and not exclude_benign

falsepositives: Users manually opening documents with Office or PDF readers
Automated document processing by legitimate enterprise software (e.g., document converters, batch printers)
System maintenance tools that open logs or configuration files

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Scheduled Task Creation via Suspicious Launchers and Long Encoded PowerShell
rules.description: Detects creation of scheduled tasks using schtasks.exe, or execution of cmd/powershell launched by mshta.exe or rundll32.exe, and flags PowerShell commands with long encoded payloads, while excluding known benign task creation tools.

detection.condition: (selection_schtasks and not selection_benign) or selection_suspicious_parent or selection_long_encoded

falsepositives: Legitimate scheduled task creation by system administrators
Software updates or maintenance tools that use schtasks.exe (e.g., Windows Update, SCCM, Intune)
Backup or monitoring solutions that launch cmd/powershell via mshta.exe or rundll32.exe for legitimate purposes

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious System Information Discovery via ipconfig with Suspicious Parent Process or Long Command Line
rules.description: Detects execution of ipconfig for system information discovery, particularly when launched from suspicious parent processes or with unusually long command lines that may indicate obfuscation.

detection.condition: selection and (suspicious_parent or long_command) and not exclusion

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative use of ipconfig via command prompt or scripts initiated by system processes
Network troubleshooting tools that invoke ipconfig through explorer.exe or cmd.exe
Enterprise management tools (e.g., SCCM, Intune) running discovery tasks

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Execution via WScript with Suspicious Parameters or Parent Process
rules.description: Detects execution of Visual Basic scripts using wscript.exe, particularly when launched from suspicious parent processes or with unusually long command lines that may indicate obfuscation or malicious payload delivery.

detection.condition: selection and script_selection and (suspicious_parent or long_command)

falsepositives: Administrative scripts executed via wscript.exe during legitimate software deployment (e.g., SCCM, Intune)
Legacy business applications that use embedded VBS scripts launched via wscript
User-initiated execution of local VBS scripts for automation tasks

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Create or Modify System Process via Native Windows Utilities
rules.description: Detects creation or modification of system processes (services, drivers) using sc.exe, reg.exe, wmic.exe, or PowerShell New-Service, indicating possible persistence activity (ATT&CK T1543).

detection.condition: selection_sc_create or selection_sc_config or selection_sc_start or selection_reg_add or selection_reg_delete or selection_wmic_create or selection_powershell_newservice

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity using sc.exe, reg.exe, or wmic.exe to manage services or registry keys.
Scheduled task creation via schtasks.exe (not covered by this rule).
Automated deployment scripts run by IT staff that create services.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious Application Layer Protocol Usage via Encoded Commands
rules.description: Detects processes that may be used for command and control over application layer protocols by monitoring execution of common scripting and utility binaries with encoded or unusually long command lines, while excluding known legitimate management tools.

detection.condition: ((suspicious_process and (encoded_flag or long_command)) or (parent_suspicious and suspicious_process)) and not benign_exclude

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using PowerShell with -EncodedCommand for internal automation
Software deployment tools (e.g., SCCM, Intune) invoking msiexec, bitsadmin, or certutil for package distribution
Windows Update processes that may use wuauclt.exe or bitsadmin.exe
Certificate enrollment or troubleshooting using certutil.exe

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Archive Collected Data via Compression Tools
rules.description: Detects processes that compress or archive data, especially when launched by suspicious parent processes or using encoded commands, while excluding known benign system management tools.

detection.condition: selection_compress and (selection_parent_suspicious or selection_encoded) and not selection_benign

falsepositives: Legitimate backup or archiving software (e.g., Windows Backup, third‑party backup solutions)
System administrators manually compressing files via PowerShell or command line
Scheduled tasks that run compression utilities for routine maintenance

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Scheduled Task/Job Creation via Suspicious Processes
rules.description: Detects creation of scheduled tasks or jobs using command-line tools or PowerShell with encoded commands, especially when launched by suspicious parent processes. Excludes known legitimate management tools such as SCCM, Intune, and Windows Update.

detection.condition: (selection_schtasks or selection_at or selection_wmic or selection_ps or selection_parent_mshta or selection_parent_rundll) and not benign

falsepositives: Legitimate use of schtasks.exe by IT administrators
Software deployment tools (SCCM, Intune) creating scheduled tasks
Windows Update scheduling tasks
Task Scheduler UI (taskeng.exe) launching tasks

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Detect Potential Malicious RDP Session Initiation
rules.description: Detects execution of mstsc.exe (Remote Desktop client) launched by suspicious processes or with unusually long encoded command lines, while excluding known legitimate management tools.

detection.condition: (rdp_client and (suspicious_launcher or encoded_cmd)) and not exclude_benign

falsepositives: Legitimate administrators using mstsc.exe for remote management
Remote assistance tools that invoke mstsc.exe
SCCM, Intune, or Windows Update processes that legitimately launch mstsc.exe
Scripts using mshta.exe, rundll32.exe, wscript.exe, or cscript.exe for benign automation

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

attacks.description: Simulates user opening a malicious document from Downloads folder.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens the document using the default application. No payload is executed; this simulates the initial user action in a spearphishing attack.

attacks.description: Launches a Word document with macros from temp directory using legitimate Office binary.
attacks.expected_behavior: Starts WINWORD.EXE to open a macro-enabled document from %TEMP%. In a real attack, this would trigger malicious macros. Here, only a benign file is referenced.

attacks.description: Decodes a base64-encoded script (simulating extracted attachment) and executes it via default handler.
attacks.expected_behavior: Uses certutil to decode a JavaScript file from a disguised binary, then opens it with the default application (likely WScript). This simulates execution post-attachment extraction.

attacks.command: echo 'echo \"This is a test document\"' > /tmp/document.pdf.sh && chmod +x /tmp/document.pdf.sh && /tmp/document.pdf.sh
attacks.description: Simulates a malicious shell script disguised as a PDF document. The user is tricked into downloading and executing it.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a shell script with a misleading .pdf extension, makes it executable, and runs it. Output: 'This is a test document'. The command is safe and does not persist or damage the system.

attacks.command: mkdir -p /tmp/attachment && echo 'echo \"Document opened. Please wait...\"' > '/tmp/attachment/financial_report.docm' && chmod +x '/tmp/attachment/financial_report.docm' && sh '/tmp/attachment/financial_report.docm'
attacks.description: Simulates a spearphishing attachment with a malicious macro-enabled document (e.g., .docm) that is actually a shell script. Directory is created to mimic extracted archive.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory and a file named like a malicious document, sets execute permission, and runs it via sh. Output: 'Document opened. Please wait...'. Safe and self-contained.

attacks.description: Simulates execution of a base64-encoded shell script received as an attachment. The script is decoded and executed to mimic payload delivery.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes a base64 string (which is '#!/bin/sh\necho \''This is a simulated phishing attachment.\''') into a script file, makes it executable, and runs it. Output: 'This is a simulated phishing attachment.'. No network activity or persistence.

attacks.description: Basic command to execute an HTA file from a remote server using mshta.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The HTA file will be executed, potentially allowing attackers to bypass security controls

attacks.description: Intermediate command to download and execute an HTA file using PowerShell and mshta.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The HTA file will be downloaded and executed, potentially allowing attackers to bypass security controls

attacks.description: Advanced command to download and execute an HTA file using certutil and mshta.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The HTA file will be downloaded and executed, potentially allowing attackers to bypass security controls

attacks.description: Create a reverse proxy using SSH, forwarding local port 8080 to remote port 19999 on the proxy server.
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a reverse proxy, allowing traffic from the proxy server to reach the local machine.

attacks.description: Use socat to create a proxy listening on local port 8080 and forwarding traffic to port 80 on the proxy server.
attacks.expected_behavior: Forwards local traffic to the proxy server, potentially bypassing restrictions.

attacks.description: Use curl with a proxy to demonstrate how an attacker might use a proxy to access external resources.
attacks.expected_behavior: Accesses the specified URL through the proxy, hiding the original IP address.

attacks.description: Open a text file named 'malicious.txt' in the temporary directory using Notepad, simulating user execution of a potentially malicious file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad opens a file named 'malicious.txt' in the %TEMP% directory, demonstrating how a user might inadvertently execute a malicious file by opening it.

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to display a message box with a compromising message, simulating the execution of malicious code through user interaction.
attacks.expected_behavior: A message box appears with the text 'You have been compromised.', demonstrating how malicious code can be executed through user-initiated actions.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c echo This is a test > %TEMP%\test.txt && start %TEMP%\test.txt
attacks.description: Create a text file in the temporary directory and then open it, simulating user execution of a file that could potentially contain malicious content.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named 'test.txt' is created in the %TEMP% directory with the content 'This is a test', and then the file is opened, demonstrating how a user might execute a potentially malicious file by interacting with it.

attacks.description: Opens a potentially malicious PDF file using the user's default application, relying on the user to execute the action.
attacks.expected_behavior: The default PDF viewer opens the file, potentially executing malicious code embedded within.

attacks.description: Executes a script that could contain malicious commands, relying on the user to run it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script executes with the user's privileges, potentially leading to malicious actions.

attacks.description: Opens a new terminal window and runs a potentially malicious script, relying on the user to interact with it.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new terminal opens and runs the script, which could lead to malicious activity based on user interaction.

attacks.description: Execute ipconfig command to display IP configuration
attacks.expected_behavior: Display IP configuration without any system modifications

attacks.description: Execute ping command to test network connectivity
attacks.expected_behavior: Successfully ping the local loopback address without any system modifications

attacks.description: Execute Get-Process command to list running processes
attacks.expected_behavior: List running processes without any system modifications

attacks.description: Execute a simple echo command using bash.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints 'Hello World!' to the console.

attacks.description: Execute a command to list files in the current directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files and directories in the current directory.

attacks.description: Create a new directory and then list the files in the current directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new directory named 'testdir' and then lists the files and directories in the current directory.

attacks.description: Start the Remote Manipulator System (RMS) service to simulate remote service connection
attacks.expected_behavior: The RMS service will start, allowing for potential lateral movement

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to check the status of the UltraVNC service, simulating a remote service query
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display the status of the UltraVNC service, if installed

attacks.description: Create a new service named MyRemoteService using the sc command, simulating remote service creation
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service named MyRemoteService will be created, potentially allowing for lateral movement

attacks.description: Basic example of using SSH to execute a command on a remote Linux system
attacks.expected_behavior: Successfully execute the command on the remote system and display the output

attacks.description: Intermediate example of using SSH to execute a command with elevated privileges on a remote Linux system
attacks.expected_behavior: Successfully execute the command with elevated privileges on the remote system and display the output

attacks.description: Advanced example of using SSH to execute multiple commands on a remote Linux system
attacks.expected_behavior: Successfully execute multiple commands on the remote system and display the output

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; $form = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Form; $form.Text = 'Phishing Simulation'; $form.Size = New-Object System.Drawing.Size(300,200); $form.ShowDialog()"
attacks.description: Simulate a phishing popup using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A form will pop up with the title 'Phishing Simulation'

attacks.command: echo 'This is a simulated phishing email.' > %TEMP%\phishing_simulation.txt
attacks.description: Create a file that simulates the content of a phishing email
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named 'phishing_simulation.txt' will be created in the temporary directory

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$wshell = New-Object -ComObject Wscript.Shell; $wshell.Popup('You have won a prize. Click OK to claim.', 0, 'Phishing Simulation', 64)"
attacks.description: Simulate a phishing popup using COM objects
attacks.expected_behavior: A popup will appear with a phishing simulation message

attacks.command: echo 'Please enter your password: ' > phishing.txt; cat phishing.txt
attacks.description: Basic phishing simulation by prompting the user to enter their password.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prompts the user to enter their password, simulating a basic phishing attempt.

attacks.description: Intermediate phishing simulation by downloading a phishing page and opening it in the default browser.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a benign phishing page and opens it, simulating an intermediate phishing attempt.

attacks.command: bash -c 'echo "You have been phished!" > phishing.txt; cat phishing.txt'
attacks.description: Advanced phishing simulation using bash to create and display a phishing message.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates and displays a phishing message using bash, simulating an advanced phishing attempt.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Establish a telnet connection for potential command and control channel
attacks.expected_behavior: Telnet service starts, potentially allowing for command and control channel establishment

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Compress a test file and output its contents, simulating data preparation for exfiltration
attacks.expected_behavior: A test file is compressed and its contents are displayed, demonstrating data preparation for exfiltration

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Encode a test file using certutil, simulating data encoding for exfiltration
attacks.expected_behavior: The test file is encoded and saved, demonstrating data encoding for exfiltration

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Exfiltrate data from a file using netcat to a remote server
attacks.expected_behavior: Data from the specified file is sent to the remote server over the network

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Use SSH to exfiltrate data from a remote server to the local machine
attacks.expected_behavior: Data from the remote server is retrieved and saved locally

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Exfiltrate base64 encoded data over a command and control channel
attacks.expected_behavior: The specified file is encoded in base64 and sent to the remote server

attacks.description: Execute a ping command to localhost using cmd.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will ping localhost and return the results.

attacks.description: Execute an ipconfig command using cmd.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display the IP configuration of the system.

attacks.description: Execute a Get-Process command using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display a list of running processes.

attacks.description: Basic command to create a file in the temp directory using bash.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the temp directory with the content 'Hello World'.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to ping a website and save the output to a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Pings google.com once and saves the output to a file named ping_test.txt in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Advanced command to show IP configuration and save the output to a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays IP configuration and saves the output to a file named ip_config.txt in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Open a sample document from the user's Documents folder using Notepad.
attacks.expected_behavior: Launches Notepad with example.txt if it exists; creates an empty file if not present. No data is modified. Harmless and commonly seen in user activity.

attacks.description: List common document files in the user's Documents directory using legacy dir command.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs filenames of .docx and .pdf files in Documents. No recursion, limited scope. Mimics attacker reconnaissance of available documents.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { Get-ChildItem -Path $env:USERPROFILE\Documents -Filter '*.txt' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue | ForEach-Object { Start-Process notepad.exe -ArgumentList $_.FullName -WindowStyle Hidden } } catch { }"
attacks.description: Use PowerShell to silently open each .txt file in the Documents folder with Notepad in hidden windows.
attacks.expected_behavior: Iterates over .txt files and opens each in Notepad with hidden windows. Simulates stealthy document access. Uses built-in cmdlets safely without .NET reflection or recursion.

attacks.description: List files in the current directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Display a list of files in the current directory

attacks.description: Open and view the contents of a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Display the contents of the file

attacks.description: Search for a specific pattern within files
attacks.expected_behavior: Display the lines containing the pattern

attacks.command: schtasks /create /tn "Startup Task" /tr "cmd /c echo Hello World > $env:TEMP\startup.txt" /sc onstart
attacks.description: Create a new scheduled task that runs a command at startup
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file 'startup.txt' will be created in the '$env:TEMP' directory at startup with the contents 'Hello World'

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v "Startup Task" /t REG_SZ /d "cmd /c echo Hello World > $env:TEMP\startup.txt" /f
attacks.description: Add a new key to the registry that runs a command at startup
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file 'startup.txt' will be created in the '$env:TEMP' directory at startup with the contents 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Create a new batch file in the startup directory that runs a command at startup
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file 'startup.txt' will be created in the '$env:TEMP' directory at startup with the contents 'Hello World'

attacks.expected_behavior: The benign script will be added to the crontab and will run on every system boot

attacks.description: Add a benign script to the system startup directory to run on every system boot
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign script will be added to the system startup directory and will run on every system boot

attacks.description: Add a benign script as a systemd service to run on every system boot
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign script will be added as a systemd service and will run on every system boot

attacks.description: Execute a Visual Basic script using cscript.exe, assuming the script is already saved as test.vbs in the %TEMP% directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The Visual Basic script test.vbs will be executed, allowing for the testing of detection rules related to Visual Basic scripting execution.

attacks.description: Create a simple Visual Basic script that displays a message box and then execute it using cscript.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: A message box with 'Hello World' will appear, demonstrating the execution of a Visual Basic script.

attacks.description: Using PowerShell, start a new process that executes a Visual Basic script named advanced_test.vbs in the %TEMP% directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The Visual Basic script advanced_test.vbs will be executed, testing the detection of script execution via PowerShell.

attacks.description: Execute a Visual Basic script using wine to run the calculator application.
attacks.expected_behavior: The calculator application should open if wine and the necessary dependencies are properly installed and configured.

attacks.command: echo "Dim objShell : Set objShell = CreateObject("WScript.Shell")" > test.vbs && echo "objShell.Run "notepad"" >> test.vbs && wine wscript test.vbs
attacks.description: Create a Visual Basic script that runs notepad and execute it using wine.
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad should open if wine and the necessary dependencies are properly installed and configured.

attacks.command: echo "CreateObject("WScript.Shell").Run "cmd /c echo Hello World"" | wine vbscript.dll
attacks.description: Execute a command using Visual Basic scripting through wine to print 'Hello World' to the console.
attacks.expected_behavior: The string 'Hello World' should be printed to the console if wine and the necessary dependencies are properly installed and configured.

attacks.description: Lists all running services on the system, which can be used to create or modify system processes
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all running services on the system

attacks.command: sc create testsvc binpath= "C:\\Windows\\System32\\svchost.exe -k netsvcs" type= own start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a new service on the system, which can be used to create or modify system processes
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new service on the system

attacks.description: Stops all services on the system that have a name like 'test', which can be used to modify system processes
attacks.expected_behavior: Stops all services on the system that have a name like 'test'

attacks.description: Create a new transient service using systemd-run
attacks.expected_behavior: A new transient service is created and runs the sleep command for 100 seconds

attacks.description: Schedule a new cron job to run daily at midnight
attacks.expected_behavior: A new cron job is scheduled to run daily at midnight, executing the true command

attacks.description: Modify a copy of the sshd service file
attacks.expected_behavior: A copy of the sshd service file is modified with an empty ExecStart directive

attacks.description: Simulate C2 activity by connecting to a benign HTTP server using telnet
attacks.expected_behavior: Establish a connection to the specified server and port, simulating C2 traffic

attacks.description: Simulate encoded command execution by establishing a TCP connection to a benign server using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Establish a TCP connection to the specified server and port, simulating encoded C2 traffic

attacks.description: Simulate C2 activity by downloading a benign file using certutil and displaying its contents
attacks.expected_behavior: Download the specified file to the temporary directory and display its contents, simulating C2 file transfer

attacks.description: Establish a basic connection to a remote server using netcat, simulating command and control communication.
attacks.expected_behavior: A connection is established to the specified server, demonstrating the ability to communicate over the application layer.

attacks.description: Use curl to send a POST request with test data to a remote server, simulating data transfer over an application layer protocol.
attacks.expected_behavior: The test data is sent to the server, and the server's response is received, demonstrating the ability to transfer data over the application layer.

attacks.description: Use netcat to listen on a local port and save received data to a file, simulating a command and control server.
attacks.expected_behavior: The netcat server listens on the specified port, and any data received is saved to the file, demonstrating the ability to receive and store data over the application layer.

attacks.description: Create an archive of all files in the user's temporary directory using PowerShell's Compress-Archive cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: An archive named 'archive.zip' will be created in the user's temporary directory containing all files from that directory.

attacks.description: Create a tar archive of all files in the user's temporary directory using the tar command.
attacks.expected_behavior: A tar archive named 'archive.tar.gz' will be created in the user's temporary directory containing all files from that directory.

attacks.description: Create a zip archive of all files in the user's temporary directory using .NET's ZipFile class in PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip archive named 'archive2.zip' will be created in the user's temporary directory containing all files from that directory.

attacks.description: Basic archiving of collected data using tar.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a tar archive named collected_data.tar.gz containing the data from /path/to/data.

attacks.description: Intermediate archiving using find and tar for more complex data collection.
attacks.expected_behavior: Finds all files in /path/to/data and archives them into collected_data.tar.gz.

attacks.description: Advanced archiving by changing directory before archiving.
attacks.expected_behavior: Changes into /path/to/data and archives its contents into collected_data.tar.gz.

attacks.description: Create a new scheduled task that runs whoami.exe daily
attacks.expected_behavior: A new task named 'TestTask' is created and runs whoami.exe daily

attacks.description: Delete a scheduled task by its name
attacks.expected_behavior: The task named 'TestTask' is deleted if it exists

attacks.description: Query all scheduled tasks on the system
attacks.expected_behavior: A list of all scheduled tasks on the system is displayed

attacks.description: Opens the cron table for editing in the default editor, allowing for the addition of new scheduled tasks.
attacks.expected_behavior: The user's cron table will be opened for editing, allowing them to add, modify, or delete scheduled tasks.

attacks.description: Appends a new cron job to the user's existing cron table. This command adds a task that runs /path/to/your/script.sh daily at midnight.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new cron job will be added to the user's cron table, scheduling the execution of script.sh daily at midnight.

attacks.description: Opens the cron table for a specified user for editing, allowing for the management of scheduled tasks for that user. Requires admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: The cron table for the specified user will be opened for editing, allowing for the addition, modification, or deletion of scheduled tasks for that user.

attacks.description: Establish a basic RDP connection to the local machine.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens an RDP connection window to the local machine.

attacks.description: Connect to the local machine via RDP with a prompt for credentials, simulating an intermediate level of interaction.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prompts for credentials before establishing the RDP connection to the local machine.

attacks.description: An advanced scenario using PowerShell to start the RDP client with arguments, demonstrating indirect command execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Starts the RDP client from PowerShell, prompting for credentials before connecting to the local machine.

attacks.description: Basic RDP connection to a Windows machine using xfreerdp
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a remote desktop connection to the specified Windows machine

attacks.description: Intermediate RDP connection using rdesktop with specified credentials
attacks.expected_behavior: Connects to the remote desktop with the given username and password

attacks.description: Advanced RDP connection with specific desktop size and ignoring certificate warnings
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a remote desktop connection with a specified desktop size and ignores any certificate warnings
